Total receipts for the year ending last June were 29,374. 28, of which 8,480,99 was a balance carried over from the year before. Receipts for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1929 totaled only 27,674.68, Expenditures for pauper ca ses and poor house expense were practically the same thit year as last Less money vn. spent for poor house cases anc more for aid outside the poo house, but there is little diff erence in the total. The school appropriation made for county funds to ena ble the schools to complete tht term was cut this year to less than half the amount appropri ated the year before- In 1928 29 the supervisors appropriat ed 2,600 and in 1929-30, on ly  1,200 was appropriated. Expenses for maintaining h clerks office, court house anc jail this year were 623.34 while for-last year they amoun ed to 1,247.26. However, in surance on the three building, was included in the expense., of last year. . Lunacy and feeble-mindec commissions this year cost th county 144.80. while las year they cost 111.10 Ther was a cut of about 300 in th salaries paid county officer, this year. The total salarie paid was 5,577.20, as compar ed with 5,863.70 of last year The county appropriated S 241.54 last year for roads an 3,00815 this year The amour, allowed for stock and fowls k, led by dogs was 135-54 th? year, more than twice th 58.20 allowed last year. Each year the funds made available to the American Cancer Society through the pub lics generosity are spent to in crease the effectiveness of the So cietys three-fold program of ser vice, education and research. The Lions Club, the Home Dem onstration Clubs and the American Legion Auxiliary are co-sponsoring this drive. Hon. J. W. Flood and MaVor G. B. Buchanan, represent ing the Lions Club, will solocitthe business concerns. County churches and rural communities will be con tacted by members of the. Home Demonstration Clubs. document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: RESOLUTIONS WHEREAS, on August 9th, 1960, God in His all-wise Providence call ed from our midset to her Eternal home, our member and friend, Mfs. Clara Matilda Mann Moses and WHERAS, she had been a faith ful and consistent member Of Me morial Methodist Church, Appomat tox, Virginia, for more than fifty years, and had given herself unre servedly to the entire program of work by regular attendance at all services, giving of her means, and maintaining a strong faith and deep interest in the cause of Christ, eveh throughout the long days she was confined to her home by the in firmities of age aad WHEREAS, she was a . deoted wife and Mkxther, a trusted friend and a kind, sympathetic neighbor, in Whose daily life the virtues of. Christian character found distinct expression, and whose passing has left a vacancy which will be keenly felt by the entire community THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLV ED-. FIRST That we offer this tri bute of respect to her memory, and record our expression of apprecia tion for her unfailing support of this Church and this organization through the years SECOND That we express to her Family eur sincere sympathy ia their loss, which we share, and com mend them to the sustaining power of Him, who is the source of all comfort and help THIRD That a copy of these re solutions be piibligfhed in The Timtm- Virginian, a copy sent to the Fam ily and a copy spread upon the min utes of this Society. Mrs. Lottie Bledsoe Mrs. H. M, Burge Mrs. Claude W. Smith Committee. 1 The Womans Society of Christian Service, Memorial Methodist Church, Appomattox, Virginia. 14c

document.text: Ms Elizabeth Lobelia LeGrand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Josejph LeGrand, of Appomattox, became the bride of Forrest Luth- ar Yeakley, son of Mrs. Martin Luther Yeakley, of Martinslwrg, W. a ., and the late Reverend Yeakley, in a garden wedding on Saturday, July 17, at 4 ociock, at her home. The Rev. J. Marshall Walker officiated. Mrs. Claude W. Smith, p.anist, and Miss Nancy Stuart Scott, soloist, presented a program of music before the cere mony. The bride, who was giv.jn in mar riage by her ftaher, wore her moth ers wedding gown of ivory satin and vajenciennes lace with match ing mitts. Her finger tip veil of illusion fell from a coronet of orange blossoms. She carried white roses and stephanotis. Mrs. Robert Lyle Carter, of Roanoke, sister of thj bride, was matron of honor. She wore aqua taffeta and carried yellow roses showered with babys breath. Foster Surface, of Fairfax, ser ved as best man. A reception was held after the ceremony.

document.text: Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Tucker Me- Dearmon, wife of Clarence Stickley MeDearmon, died Tuesday at her home here after an illness of about three years. She was born at Nysalta, in Am herst County, the daughter of the late John Wilbur Fiske Tncker and Mary Richard Smith Tucker. She at tended schools in Amherst County and the Gooch School in Danville. She was a member of Memorial Methodist Church. Besides her husband, she is sur vived by three sons, James Wilbur and C. Lewis MeDearmon, of Appo mattox, and John Richard Tucker MeDearmon, of Richmond three daughters, Mrs. Frances McD. Cheat ham, of Appomattox Mrs. Sam B. Witt, Jr., of Fichmond, and Miss Mildred MeDearmon, of Columbia, S. C. and five grandchildren. Funeral services were held Wed nesday at 330 P. M, at the resi dence. Burial was in Liberty Ceme tery. Active pallbearers were Dr. David A. Christian, HI Claude W. Smith, J. A. Burke, Robert Doss, S. L. Ferguson, Jr. Harry MeDear mon, Floyd A. Porter and Walter Tucker, Jr.

document.text: Mrs. Claude W. Smith, of Appo mattox is the author of the medita tion being used on Thursday, Janu ary 7, by an estimated seven million people who are readers of The Up per Room. The Upper Room, a de votional guide under the editorship of Dr. J. Manning Potts, has a cir culation of more than two and a half million copies in the English editions published. It is also published in Braille and two other English edi tions, as well as in seventeen other languages. Mrs. Smith based her meditation on Luke 111, Lord, teach us to pray. She says in part Just as oxygen is necessary to keep us alive physically, so is prayer necessary to keep us alive spiritually. It is the channel through which we commune with God, and through which His power flows into our lives. If He needed to pray, how much more we need to exercise this privilege to seek Gods power through prayer. The meditation is concluded with a prayer and a thought for the day. Because of the wide readership and popularity of The Upper Room it is considered a high honor to have a meditation selected and published in this devotional guide. Mrs. Smiths meditation, with the others in the January, February is sue, is a part of the ministry of 60,000 churches in the United States and Canada. These churches repre sent every Protestant denomination.

document.text: MRS. CLAUDE W. SMITH back from the makes report. enee LONDON.  Money always came easily to Sydney E. Parkes, so eas ily that at 65 he is fed up with being a Midas. At least he said as much when London reporters found him at home recently. Whats the use of a big. fortune Parkes income is something like 430,000 pounds a year.  when I have to get my collars made of material cut from my shirt tails? he .demanded gloomily, adding with a soupcon of bitterness Well, perhaps you can understand how it feels to be rich. The reporters could not, but they nodded agreement with the notion that making one pound every min ute was one of those things in life that couldnt be helped and had to be put up with as stoically as might be. Id give every penny I have to be 30 again, Parkes sighed as he sank back in his armchair and clouded the circumambient air with smoke from one of his 100 pipes. Owns Three Dog Traeks. Parkes was ensconced beside the fire in his Georgian home, Devon shire house, Wandsworth, which he had bought a few weeks previously with its 28-acre estate, said to be the largest private property in the London county council area. He owns three greyhound racing sta diums and was being interviewed about a dispute between book makers and Wandsworth sta dium over betting pitches, which had just been decided in the high court. It was during this talk he revealed that his personal income last year was 430,000 pounds. It mostly went in income tax, he said. I got 4,800 pounds on the first 20,000 pounds, and after that only 6 pence in the pound10,000 rounds at the most. The rest I

Simpkins and daughter, Edythe, of Mpunt Hope, W. Va., spent the week-end with her father, J. W. Cawthon. document.text: Mr. Fletcher T. Guill, 65, died Saturday at 1150 A. M., at his home here. Born in Appomattox County, he was the son of the late Nathaniel and Willie Viar Guill. He was a member of Memorial Methodist Church. He was a retired mechanic. He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Sadie Doss Guill seven sons, Jessie T, Wilson, Joe, Burke, Tom and Hal F. Guill, all of Appomattox, and Charlie Guill, of Arlington three brothers, Thomas and Herman Guill, of Appomattox, and Sam Guill, of Norfolk one sister, Mrs. Virginia Goodman, of Lynchburg, and by 19 grandchildren and four great grand children. Funeral services were held Mon day at 200 P. M. from Memorial Methodist Church, conducted by the Rev. Richard Bergdoll, who was as sisted by Dr. Carl A. Collins, Jr. Mrs. Carter Martin offeerd a sola, and Mrs. Claude W. Smith accom panied her at the piano. Pallbearers were eight grandsons J. T. Guill Jr., Charlie, Bobby, Pete, Carlton, Freddie, Dickie and Qtto- way Guill.

document.text: MEMORIAL CHURCH ACTIVITIES Holy Communion will be served at both Services Sunday, resuming the monthly observance of the Holy Eucharist. These services will mark the beginning of the second quarter of the durrent con ference Year, and be a special call for a Back to the Church! move following the Summer Season. The pastor will continue the Series of Messages from the Prophets, speak ing Sunday from the Prophecy of Ezekiel. A the evening service, 630 Oclock, the Sermon Subject will be taken from the Ten Com mandments, speaking Sunday even ing oh the Seventh Commandment, Thou Shalt Not Commit Adultery. The Sanctuary Choir will furnish special music for the Morning Hour and the Chapel Choir will give a Special Number, for the  Evening Service.  The monthly official Board meet ing, Claude W. Smith, Chairman, wiH meet at the Church, Wednesday 30 Oclock to plan the Fall Rally Program of the Congregation. At 815 P. M. the Commission on Chris tian Social Relations will meet for organization and planning meeting, Mrs. Ivey Holland, Chairman.
